docs.text: Hello! I'm LeValle Bradix and welcome to my technical writing portfolio! I'm excited to share the work I've created while learning and growing as a technical communicator. docs.title: Installing Linux Mint (Step-by-Step Guide for Beginners)
docs.text: Linux Mint is a beginner-friendly, full-featured Linux distribution that's perfect for new and experienced users alike. Providing an easy transition from the Windows environment, this is an excellent first choice within the Linux realm. This guide walks you through installing Linux Mint on your machine, whether you’re replacing an existing OS or setting up dual-boot.

docs.title: 📋 Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A USB flash drive (8GB or larger)
  • Access to a working computer with internet
  • Basic familiarity with boot menus and BIOS/UEFI settings
  • Optional: Backup your existing data

docs.title: 1. Download Linux Mint
docs.text:
1. Visit the official Linux Mint website.
  2. Choose a desktop environment (Cinnamon is the default).

  3. Download the latest ISO file.

    Choose the closest mirror to your location for faster download speeds.

docs.title: 2. Create a Bootable USB
docs.text:
Use a tool like:

  • Windows: Rufus, balenaEtcher
  • macOS: balenaEtcher
  • Linux: Use the dd command or USB Creator tool
Steps using Rufus
  1. Insert USB drive.
  2. Open Rufus and select your downloaded ISO.
  3. Click Start and wait for the process to complete.
Steps using balenaEtcher
  1. Insert USB drive.
  2. Open balenaEtcher and select flash from file.
  3. Open your downloaded ISO.
  4. Click select target and select USB.
  5. Flash!
Steps using Linux

Option 1: USB Creator Tool 1. Insert USB drive. 2. Open "USB Image Writer" 3. Select ISO and choose the USB. 4. Click Write, enter password when prompted. 5. Done!

Option 2: dd command 1. Insert your USB and find its device name. Run: lsblk 2. Navigate to the directory with the ISO cd ~/Downloads 3. Write the ISO to USB Replace /dev/sdX with the correct device (e.g., /dev/sdb): sudo dd if=kdeneon-useredition-current.iso of=/dev/sdX bs=4M status=progress oflag=sync 4. Wait for the process to finish. It can take several minutes. Once you see a prompt again, it's done. 5. Eject the USB safely. sudo eject /dev/sdX

docs.title: 3. Boot from the USB Drive
docs.text:
1. Restart your computer and enter the boot menu:

  2. Common keys: F12, ESC, DEL, or F2

    Confirm BIOS SATA operation is set to AHCI, not RAID.

  3. Select the USB device from the list.

  4. Choose "Start Linux Mint" from the boot menu.

docs.title: 4. Install Linux Mint
docs.text:
Once the live environment loads:

  1. Click the "Install Linux Mint" icon on the desktop.
  2. Choose your language and keyboard layout.
  3. Connect to internet (optional)

  4. Installation type:

    • Replace existing OS
    • Install alongside Windows (dual-boot)
    • Manual partitioning (advanced users)

  5. Follow the prompts to:

    • Set time zone
    • Create a computer name, username, and password
    • Begin installation

    Double-check your partitioning choices, this step can delete data.

docs.title: 5. First Boot & Updates
docs.text:
After installation:

  1. Remove your USB when prompted.
  2. Restart your computer.
  3. Log in with your new user account.

  4. Run: 

    sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade
    to install latest updates.

    Passwords typed in the terminal are invisible.

docs.title: Final Thoughts
docs.text: 🎉 Congrats! You have now successfully installed Linux Mint. From here focus on setting up different apps, customizing the desktop or moving over data. Make it feel like home.

docs.title: Joining Ubuntu-Based Linux Devices to Windows Server 2025 Active Directory (Winbind Method)
docs.text: Use this guide to join a Debian/Ubuntu-based Linux system (like KDE Neon, Mint or Zorin) to a Windows Server 2025 AD domain using winbind, samba, and Kerberos.

docs.title: 📋 Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Windows Server 2025 configured as Domain Controller
  • Domain name
  • AD server IP
  • Domain join account
  • Linux client with sudo access

docs.title: 1. Set hostname
docs.text:
• Run:
sudo hostnamectl set-hostname <your-hostname>
sudo nano /etc/hosts

  • Replace any instance of the old hostname.

  • Reboot:

sudo reboot

docs.title: 2. Set dns to the ad server
docs.text:
• Point /etc/resolv.conf to your server: 
sudo nano /etc/resolv.conf
  • Add:
nameserver <server-IP>
search <domain-name>

docs.title: 3. Install required packages
docs.text:
• Run:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install samba krb5-user winbind libpam-winbind libnss-winbind -y
  • When prompted the Kerberos installer, enter your default realm.
  • Leave other prompts blank and press Enter.

docs.title: 4. Configure Kerberos
docs.text:
sudo nano /etc/krb5.conf

  • Update to:
[libdefaults]
    default_realm = <domain-name>
    dns_lookup_realm = false
    dns_lookup_kdc = true

docs.title: 5. Configure Samba
docs.text:
• Backup and replace /etc/samba/smb.conf:
sudo cp /etc/samba/smb.conf /etc/samba/smb.conf.bak
sudo nano /etc/samba/smb.conf
  • Paste in:

[global]
  workgroup = <workgroup>
  realm = <domain-name>
  security = ads
  client signing = yes
  client use spnego = yes
  kerberos method = secrets and keytab
  log file = /var/log/samba/%m/log
  log level = 1
  winbind refresh tickets = yes
  winbind use default domain = yes
  winbind offline logon = yes
  idmap config * : backend = tdb
  idmap config * : range = 10000-20000
  template shell = /bin/bash
  template homedir = /home/%U

How to Select all in Nano Text Editor
  1. Press "Alt + Backslash" keys together. This moves the cursor to the start of the file.
  2. Press "Ctrl + 6" keys together. This sets a mark at the current cursor position.
  3. Press "Alt + Forward Slash" keys together. This moves the cursor to the end of the file.
  4. Press "Ctrl Shift K keys together. This will clear all selected text.

docs.title: 6. Configure nss
docs.text:
sudo nano /etc/nsswitch.conf - Add winbind to these lines:

passwd:         compat winbind
group:          compat winbind
shadow:         compat

docs.title: 7. Restart services
docs.text:
sudo systemctl restart smbd nmbd winbind
  • Enable on boot:
sudo systemctl enable winbind

docs.title: 8. Test kerberos and join domain
docs.text:
• Test authentication: 
kinit <domain-user>

You'll most likely see a password expiration message, that's fine.

  • Then join: 
sudo net ads join -U <domain-user>

Seeing DNS update failed is normal.

docs.title: 9. Test identity resolution
docs.text:
wbinfo -u     # List domain users
wbinfo -g     # List domain groups
getent passwd <domain-user>

docs.title: 10. Enable domain login and home creation
docs.text:
• Edit PAM and enable home dir creation: 
sudo pam-auth-update

Below is what your pam settings should look like:

docs.title: 11. Reboot and log in
docs.text:
sudo reboot - Log in with domain user credentials. - The system will create a home folder for the user.

Success! Your Linux device is now joined to the Windows Server 2025 Active Directory domain using the winbind.

docs.title: * kinit: Cannot find KDC for realm "<REALM>"
docs.text:
Fix: - Ensure /etc/resolv.conf points to your DC IP - Verify default_realm is UPPERCASE in /etc/krb5.conf - Test DNS: 

dig <domain-name>

docs.title: * net ads join returns DNS update failed!
docs.text: Fix: Usually safe to ignore if you can log in and resolve domain names.

docs.title: * Login fails after join
docs.text:
Fix: - Ensure winbind is running: 

sudo systemctl status winbind
- Re-run: 
sudo pam-auth-update

docs.title: * getent passwd <domain-user> returns nothing
docs.text:
Fix: - Check /etc/nsswitch.conf has winbind on the correct lines. - Restart windbind: 

sudo systemct restart winbind

docs.title: * winbind -u and -g return nothing
docs.text: Fix: - Validate /etc/samba/smb.conf and /etc/krb5.conf formatting. - Ensure realm and workgroup are correct.

docs.title: Setting Up MkDocs with Material Theme on Linux Mint
docs.text: A step-by-step guide to creating a professional documentation site using MkDocs and GitHub Pages.

docs.title: 📋 Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Linux Mint installed
  • GitHub account
  • Terminal access
  • Visual Studio Code
  • Python

docs.title: 1. Install git and github cli
docs.text:
• Open terminal and input: 
    sudo apt update   
sudo apt install git gh      
gh auth login

docs.title: 2. Set up a new mkdocs project
docs.text: mkdocs new my-new-docs

docs.title: 3. Create a virtual environment
docs.text:
1. Open Visual Studio Code
  2. Open new terminal inside Visual Studio Code 
    cd my-new-docs
python3 -m venv venv  
source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: 4. Install pip
docs.text: sudo apt install python3-pip

docs.title: 5. Install mkdocs and the material theme
docs.text: pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material

docs.title: 6. Customize your mkdocs.yml
docs.text:
• Set attributes site_name, theme, palette, font, favicon, and more
  • Find detailed customization information here
  • Add Markdown extension for Visual Studio Code compatibility: 
markdown_extensions:
  - pymdownx.mark

docs.title: 7. Preview your site locally
docs.text: mkdocs serve * View in browser at: http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: 8. Push to github and deploy
docs.text:
git init
git remote add origin https://github.com/<your-username>/my-new-docs.git
git add .
git config --global user.email "you@example.com"
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git push -u origin main
mkdocs gh-deploy

docs.title: 9. Enable github pages
docs.text:
1. Go to repo ⚙ Settings → Pages
  2. Set branch to gh-pages, root folder, and save

    Below is what your GitHub Pages settings should look like:

Success!

  • Your site should be available at: https://<your-username>.github.io/my-new-docs/

Don't Forget to Deploy
  • After updating .md files run mkdocs serve for local updates.
  • For public updates run the following: 
    git add .  
git commit -m "My update message"  
git push  
mkdocs gh-deploy
  • ⏱️ Note public updates can take 1-3 minutes to apply.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Full Disk Issues on Linux Servers
docs.text: Audience: System Administrators, Home Lab Users, DevOps Last Updated: July 2025 Author: LeValle Bradix

docs.title: Symptoms
docs.text:
You may encounter one or more of the following:

  • No space left on device errors
  • Failed systemd services or application crashes
  • Inability to write files or restart processes
  • Cron jobs or backup tasks failing
  • System becomes unresponsive or fails to boot

docs.title: Immediate Checks
docs.text:
1. Check overall disk usage: 

    df -h

  2. Find large directories: 

    sudo du -sh /* 2>/dev/null | sort -h

  3. Check inside /var (commonly problematic): 

    sudo du -sh /var/* | sort -h

  4. Look for large log files: 

    sudo find /var/log -type f -size +50M

docs.title: Safe Cleanup Actions
docs.text:
Always verify before deleting. Use ls -lh to inspect.

Rotate or delete logs: 

sudo journalctl --vacuum-size=100M
sudo rm -f /var/log/*.gz /var/log/*.[0-9]

Clean apt/yum cache:

  • Debian/Ubuntu: 
    sudo apt clean
  • RHEL/Fedora: 
    sudo dnf clean all

Clear thumbnail or temp files (desktop systems): 

rm -rf ~/.cache/thumbnails/*
sudo rm -rf /tmp/*

docs.title: Root Cause Analysis
docs.text:
• Did a service generate excessive logs? (/var/log/syslog, journald)
  • Did backups or cron jobs write to the wrong location?
  • Are containers, VMs, or snapshots eating space?
  • Was logrotate or a cleanup script misconfigured?

docs.title: Preventive Measures
docs.text:
• Enable log rotation: 

    sudo nano /etc/logrotate.conf

  • Schedule a monthly disk usage audit via cron: 

    crontab -e
# Add:
0 7 1 * * df -h | mail -s "Monthly Disk Report" your@email.com

  • Monitor disk usage with tools like:

    • ncdu
    • glances
    • netdata or grafana

docs.title: When to Escalate or Reboot
docs.text:
• Root (/) partition is full and blocking critical services
  • You can't delete anything safely
  • Disk hardware is failing (use smartctl, dmesg)

docs.title: Quick Fix Checklist
docs.text:
• df -h run, issue confirmed
  • Large folders identified via du -sh
  • Logs or cache cleaned
  • Root cause documented
  • Prevention in place

Pro Tip: Keep /var/log, /tmp, and /home on separate partitions when possible to isolate failures.

docs.title: Vaultwarden User Guide
docs.text:
Secure your digital life with a self-hosted password manager.

Welcome to the Vaultwarden User Guide. This documentation is designed to help individuals securely manage their passwords, notes, and sensitive data using the Vaultwarden platform — a lightweight, self-hosted alternative to Bitwarden.

Whether you're brand new to password managers or transitioning from a cloud-based service, this guide will walk you through everything you need to know as an end user.

docs.title: What You’ll Learn
docs.text:
• How to log into your Vaultwarden account
  • How to store, organize, and retrieve your credentials
  • How to enable two-factor authentication (2FA)
  • How to use the browser extension for autofill
  • How to securely share credentials with others

docs.title: Who Is This For?
docs.text:
This guide is intended for end users of Vaultwarden — not system administrators or developers. If your Vaultwarden instance is already set up, you’re in the right place.

If you’re looking to install or configure Vaultwarden, check the official GitHub repository.

docs.title: Vaultwarden Best Practices
docs.text: Using a password manager is one of the best steps you can take to improve your online security. Here are some recommended practices to help you get the most out of Vaultwarden.

docs.title: Use a Strong Master Password
docs.text:
• Choose a long passphrase (e.g., a sentence with random words).
  • Avoid using personal details or reused passwords.
  • Store your master password in a secure, offline location (e.g., a physical notebook or password-protected file).

Remember: Your master password cannot be recovered. If you forget it, your vault is permanently inaccessible.

docs.title: Enable Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)
docs.text:
• Use an authenticator app like Google Authenticator or Authy.
  • Enable 2FA as soon as possible under Account Settings → Security → Two-Step Login.
  • Save backup codes in a secure location.

2FA adds a critical layer of protection, especially if your email is compromised.

docs.title: Keep Your Vault Organized
docs.text:
• Use folders to group related items (e.g., “Work,” “Finance,” “Personal”).
  • Name entries clearly (e.g., “Gmail - Personal” vs. “Gmail - Work”).
  • Use favorites ☆ for logins you use daily.

docs.title: Clean Up Regularly
docs.text:
• Delete unused or duplicate items.
  • Review shared items to make sure access is still appropriate.
  • Reorganize your vault if it starts to feel cluttered.

docs.title: Update Passwords Often
docs.text:
• Rotate passwords for high-value accounts (e.g., email, banking).
  • If you hear about a breach, change that account’s password immediately.
  • Use the password generator when creating new accounts.

docs.title: Be Cautious with Shared Items
docs.text:
• Only share what’s necessary.
  • Use Collections in Organizations to restrict access.
  • Never share your master password or 2FA codes.

docs.title: Log Out on Shared Devices
docs.text:
• Always log out of the browser extension and web app when using a public or shared computer.
  • Consider using Incognito Mode or a private browser session for extra safety.

docs.title: Using the Vaultwarden Browser Extension
docs.text: Vaultwarden works seamlessly with the official Bitwarden browser extension. This allows you to quickly fill in passwords, save new logins, and access your vault without opening the full web app.

docs.title: Step 1: Install the Browser Extension
docs.text:
Choose your browser and install the Bitwarden extension:

  • Chrome Web Store
  • Firefox Add-ons
  • Edge Add-ons

docs.title: Step 2: Log Into the Extension
docs.text:
1. Click the extension icon.
  2. On the login screen, click Settings.
  3. Under Server URL, replace the default with your self-hosted Vaultwarden address (e.g., https://vault.bradix.org).
  4. Go back and log in with your email and master password.

If you don't change the Server URL, the extension will try to connect to Bitwarden's cloud servers instead of your Vaultwarden instance.

docs.title: Step 3: Using the Extension
docs.text:
Once logged in, the Bitwarden icon (a shield 🛡️) will appear near your address bar.

Now you can:

  • View and search your vault
  • Autofill login forms
  • Copy usernames or passwords
  • Add new items on the fly

docs.title: Autofill a Login
docs.text:
1. Navigate to a website with a saved login.
  2. Click the extension icon.
  3. If the site is recognized, your login(s) will appear.
  4. Click the one you want to autofill.

docs.title: Save a New Login
docs.text:
1. Log into a new site manually.
  2. After submitting, the extension will show the below prompt:
  3. Click Save to save it to your vault.

You can organize items by editing them in the web vault afterward.

docs.title: Locking & Unlocking the Vault
docs.text:
• Login → Settings → Account security
  • Set a PIN code to unlock quickly.
  • Choose to lock the vault:
    • When the browser is closed
    • After a timeout period
    • Manually
Clear Vault Cache on Shared Devices

If you're using a shared or public computer, always:

  1. Log out of the extension
  2. Clear browser data (or use Incognito Mode)

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
docs.text: This section covers common questions and problems users encounter when using Vaultwarden.

docs.title: I forgot my master password. Can I reset it?
docs.text:
Unfortunately, no.

Vaultwarden (like Bitwarden) uses zero-knowledge encryption, meaning no one—not even the administrator—can recover your master password. If it's lost, your data is permanently inaccessible.

Use a password hint or save your master password securely offline.

docs.title: I didn’t receive a login or verification email. What should I do?
docs.text:
Check the following:

  • Look in your Spam or Junk folder.
  • Make sure you're using the correct email address.
  • If the server is self-hosted, the admin may need to configure email (SMTP) settings.

Contact your Vaultwarden admin if the issue persists.

docs.title: The browser extension says “Cannot connect to server.” What’s wrong?
docs.text:
Most likely, the Server URL is not set correctly.

  1. Click the Settings link in the browser extension login screen.
  2. Replace the default server URL (https://vault.bitwarden.com) with your self-hosted Vaultwarden instance URL (e.g., https://vault.bradix.org).
  3. Save and try logging in again.

docs.title: Can I use Vaultwarden on mobile?
docs.text:
Yes!

  • Download the Bitwarden mobile app from the App Store or Google Play Store.
  • In Settings, change the Server URL to your Vaultwarden instance.
  • Log in with your credentials.

The mobile app works just like the browser extension, including autofill and vault sync.

docs.title: How do I back up my vault?
docs.text:
You can export your vault to a file:

  1. Go to Tools → Export Vault.
  2. Enter your master password.
  3. Download the file in CSV or JSON format.

Exported vault files are unencrypted! Store them securely and delete them when finished.

docs.title: Is Vaultwarden safe?
docs.text:
Vaultwarden is a secure, self-hosted alternative to Bitwarden. It uses:

  • End-to-end encryption
  • Zero-knowledge architecture
  • Open-source code (auditable on GitHub)

Security also depends on how you use it—strong passwords, 2FA, and safe sharing are essential.

docs.title: Getting Started with Vaultwarden
docs.text: Welcome! In this section, we’ll walk through how to access Vaultwarden, create your account (if needed), and log in for the first time.

docs.title: 📋 Requirements
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have the following:

  • An invite email or registration link (provided by your admin)
  • A modern web browser (Firefox, Chrome, Edge, etc.)

docs.title: Step 1: Access the Web Interface
docs.text:
1. Open your browser.
  2. Go to the Vaultwarden URL provided by your admin.
  3. You should see a login screen like this:

docs.title: Step 2: Create an Account
docs.text:
If your instance allows new user registration:

  1. Click Create Account.
  2. Fill in your email address and create a strong master password.
  3. Click Submit.

Your master password is not recoverable. Choose wisely and store it in a safe place.

If your instance does not allow open registration, ask your admin for an invitation.

docs.title: Step 3: Log In
docs.text:
1. Enter your email and master password.
  2. Click Log In.
  3. You should now see your empty vault dashboard.
First-Time Setup Tips
  • Save your master password in a physical notebook or a separate secure place.
  • Enable 2FA as soon as possible (we'll cover this in the User Settings section).
  • Install the browser extension for autofill features.

docs.title: Managing Your Vault
docs.text: Once you're logged into Vaultwarden, your vault is your personal storage space for secure information. This includes logins, credit cards, secure notes, and identity details. Here's how to manage it all.

docs.title: Adding a New Item
docs.text:
1. From your Vault dashboard, click the +New button.
  2. Select the item type:
  3. Login
  4. Secure Note
  5. Card
  6. Identity
  7. Fill in the necessary fields (e.g., username, password, name, notes).
  8. (Optional) Use the Password Generator to create a strong password.
  9. Click Save.

You can add custom fields if you need extra info, like recovery codes or secondary emails.

docs.title: Editing an Item
docs.text:
1. From the Vault list, click on the item you want to edit.
  2. Click the Edit button.
  3. Make your changes.
  4. Click Save.

docs.title: Deleting an Item
docs.text:
1. Open the item you want to delete.
  2. Click the red trash bin icon or Delete button.
  3. Confirm deletion when prompted.

Deleted items are not recoverable unless your Vaultwarden admin has backups enabled.

docs.title: Folders
docs.text:
1. Click Folders in the left sidebar.
  2. Click Add Folder.
  3. Enter a folder name and save.
  4. When editing or adding an item, assign it to a folder from the dropdown.

docs.title: Favorite Items
docs.text: • Click the ☆ icon on any item to mark it as a Favorite for quick access.

docs.title: Searching Your Vault
docs.text:
Use the search bar at the top left to quickly find items by name, username, or URL.

Try It Out!

Practice by adding a test login, such as: - Website: https://example.com - Username: testuser@example.com - Password: Use the built-in generator

You can delete it afterward!

docs.title: Sharing Items with Others
docs.text: Vaultwarden supports secure sharing through Organizations and Collections. This is ideal for families, teams, or small businesses that need shared access to specific credentials.

docs.title: What Is an Organization?
docs.text: An Organization is a shared space where multiple users can collaborate and manage shared vault items.

docs.title: Example Use Cases:
docs.text:
• A family sharing Netflix and Wi-Fi credentials
  • A small IT team sharing server logins
  • A business team managing social media accounts

docs.title: What Are Collections?
docs.text:
Collections are folders within an Organization that group related items. You can control which users have access to which Collections.

Example Collections: - "Finance Logins" - "Team Tools" - "Social Media"

docs.title: Creating or Joining an Organization
docs.text:
Only Vaultwarden admins or invited users can create or join an Organization.

  1. Go to the Organizations tab in the Vaultwarden web interface.
  2. Click New Organization (if available), or accept an invite from an existing one.
  3. Enter your organization name and billing email (if applicable).
  4. Confirm creation and start adding users and Collections.

docs.title: Adding Users to an Organization
docs.text:
1. Navigate to your Organization.
  2. Go to Manage Users.
  3. Click Invite User and enter their email.
  4. Choose their role:
  5. Owner: Full control
  6. Admin: Manage users and items
  7. User: Access assigned Collections

Invited users will receive an email to join your Organization. They must already have a Vaultwarden account.

docs.title: Sharing an Item
docs.text:
To share a login or note with your team:

  1. Edit the item in your vault.
  2. Change the Ownership from "Private" to your Organization.
  3. Assign it to one or more Collections.
  4. Click Save.

Only users with access to that Collection will be able to see and use the shared item.

docs.title: Auditing Shared Access
docs.text:
Vaultwarden lets admins view: - Who accessed what item - When an item was modified - Who owns or shares each credential

Use this for accountability and access control within your team.

Best Practices for Sharing
  • Use Collections to keep items organized
  • Give users the least privilege required
  • Regularly review shared items and user roles
  • Use 2FA for all users in an Organization

docs.title: Managing Your Account & User Settings
docs.text: Vaultwarden gives users control over their security and account preferences. This page walks through how to update your information, enable two-factor authentication (2FA), and export your vault data (if needed).

docs.title: Updating Your Account Information
docs.text:
To update your email, name, or language settings:

  1. Log into the Vaultwarden web app.
  2. Click your profile icon in the upper-right corner.
  3. Select Account Settings.
  4. Edit the fields as needed and click Save.

Changing your email address will require re-verification.

docs.title: Changing Your Master Password
docs.text:
Your master password is the key to your entire vault. To change it:

  1. Navigate to Account Settings → Security tab.
  2. Click Change Master Password.
  3. Enter your current password, then the new one twice.
  4. Click Save.

Use a long passphrase you can remember. This password cannot be recovered if lost.

docs.title: Enabling Two-Factor Authentication (2FA)
docs.text:
1. In Account Settings → Security → Two-Step Login tab.
  2. Click Manage under the providers tab.
  3. Choose Authenticator App (TOTP).

  4. Scan the QR code using an app like:

    • Google Authenticator
    • Authy
    • Microsoft Authenticator
    • Enter the generated code and click Enable.

Keep your backup codes somewhere safe. You'll need them if you lose access to your device.

docs.title: Exporting Your Vault
docs.text:
You can export your vault as an encrypted or plaintext file:

  1. Go to Tools → Export vault.
  2. Choose your export format (CSV or JSON).
  3. Re-enter your master password.
  4. Click Export vault.

Exported files are not encrypted! Only do this in a secure environment and delete the file immediately after use.

docs.title: Deleting Your Account
docs.text:
To delete your Vaultwarden account permanently:

  1. Go to Account Settings → Danger Zone.
  2. Click Delete Account.
  3. Confirm your master password and approve the deletion.

This action cannot be undone. Your vault data will be permanently lost.
